Jim,
Far from it -- nothing else in Callisto except DTP uses the particular functionality that you mention. BIRT uses only the ODA components of DTP and some basic connectivity, but it does not touch the JDBC components in DTP. WTP still has its own "rdb" components, which are similar, but a different actual components from those in DTP. Other than that, no other eclipse.org project is using this functionality.

The problems you're seeing with the generic JDBC connection profile are due to expectations put on those JDBC drivers from the SQL model. Typically you'd need to specialize the SQL model and connection profile framework for these particular cases, which is what we've done for our example database -- Apache Derby -- in DTP 0.7 and 0.9. Going forward past 0.9 to 1.0, we'll be working with various communities to make specialized components built on DTP frameworks available for specific databases, so the situation should improve greatly over time. As an eclipse.org project, we concentrate on "extensible frameworks and exemplary tools" (Apache Derby in the present case). DTP 0.9 will have this foundation in place, and then we'll build out from it, with community support for particular data sources.

DTP is used by BIRT. BIRT is used by TPTP. To UNINSTALL DTP requires uninstalling half the release.

IF DTP only supports DERBY today, then I must be pretty dumb. Where is that documented???  Is there any documentation easily available on the DTP site describing what databases are planned for support and when?

Jim,
Yes, you are correct about the DTP-->BIRT-->TPTP chain, but what you're missing is that DTP is a collection of frameworks and tools. Not all consumers use all of the tools and, as I explained earlier, none use the specific component (generic JDBC connection profile) that you are having a problem with. Actually, I think it the upcomming Callisto RC2, you should be able to just select TPTP (or BIRT) and it will only pull the components from DTP that it needs (again, which does not include the component you're having problems with). So, I really don't see the broader issue here -- the fact that DTP needs to add additional support for particular databases is not impacting other projects, since they do not rely on this functionality.

Regarding Apache Derby/other database support -- there's a number of documents on the DTP:Connectivity site that explain how to connect to Derby and work with it as an example. For the others, we are currently working on a proposal for this type of support, and expect to have something in front of the community in the next couple of weeks. (BTW, that's why this bug was set to "remind", so we can talk about it again at that point.)
